content.title: Cardiogenic Shock
content.summary: Cardiogenic shock is a state of critical end-organ hypoperfusion due to primary cardiac pump failure. It is characterized by low cardiac output, elevated filling pressures, and systemic hypoperfusion. Acute MI is the most common cause, and mortality remains high (40-50%) despite advances. Early revascularization for MI and hemodynamic support with inotropes and mechanical circulatory support are cornerstones of management.
key_points: Definition: Cardiac output inadequate for tissue perfusion despite adequate filling pressures
Hemodynamics: Low CI (<2.2 L/min/m²), high PCWP (>15 mmHg), elevated SVR
Most common cause: Acute MI (5-8% of STEMI develops cardiogenic shock)
Clinical: Hypotension, cold extremities, pulmonary edema, altered mental status
Treatment: Inotropes (dobutamine), vasopressors, early revascularization if AMI
Mechanical circulatory support: IABP, Impella, VA-ECMO for refractory cases
content.statement: Cardiogenic shock results from acute pump failure causing inadequate tissue perfusion, diagnosed by low cardiac output with elevated filling pressures, managed with hemodynamic support and urgent revascularization when caused by acute coronary syndromes.

explanation.intuition: The heart is a failing pump that cannot push blood forward. Fluid backs up into the lungs (pulmonary edema) while the body is underperfused (cold extremities, oliguria). Unlike septic shock where you give lots of fluids, here extra fluid makes it worse. You need to help the pump work better (inotropes) or temporarily replace it (MCS).
explanation.key_insight: The vicious cycle of cardiogenic shock: low CO → hypotension → decreased coronary perfusion → worsening ischemia → further decreased CO. Breaking this cycle requires inotropes/vasopressors for immediate stabilization and revascularization (PCI) for definitive treatment in MI-related shock.
explanation.technical_details: SHOCK trial established early revascularization benefit in MI-related cardiogenic shock. IABP-SHOCK II showed no mortality benefit from routine IABP. Impella and VA-ECMO increasingly used for refractory shock. CI <1.8 L/min/m² indicates severe shock with high mortality.

definitions_glossary.cardiogenic_shock: Circulatory failure from inadequate cardiac output despite adequate intravascular volume
definitions_glossary.cardiac_index: Cardiac output normalized to body surface area; normal 2.5-4 L/min/m²
definitions_glossary.PCWP: Pulmonary capillary wedge pressure; estimates left atrial and LV filling pressure
definitions_glossary.inotrope: Agent that increases myocardial contractility (dobutamine, milrinone)
definitions_glossary.vasopressor: Agent that causes vasoconstriction to increase blood pressure
definitions_glossary.dobutamine: Beta-1 agonist inotrope; increases contractility with some vasodilation
definitions_glossary.IABP: Intra-aortic balloon pump; augments diastolic coronary perfusion
definitions_glossary.Impella: Percutaneous axial flow pump providing direct LV unloading
definitions_glossary.VA_ECMO: Venoarterial extracorporeal membrane oxygenation; full circulatory support
definitions_glossary.LV_unloading: Reducing LV work and wall stress through mechanical support
definitions_glossary.revascularization: Restoring coronary blood flow via PCI or CABG

pathophysiology.mechanism: Acute reduction in cardiac output → decreased tissue perfusion → compensatory vasoconstriction (high SVR) → increased afterload worsens cardiac function → vicious cycle

causes.acute_MI: Most common (5-8% of STEMI); usually large anterior MI or RV infarct

clinical_criteria: SBP <90 mmHg for >30 min or vasopressor requirement for SBP ≥90
Evidence of end-organ hypoperfusion (altered mental status, cool extremities, oliguria, elevated lactate)
diagnostic_criteria.invasive_hemodynamics: PA catheter for PCWP, CO, SVR if diagnosis uncertain or to guide therapy

differential_diagnosis: Septic shock (warm extremities, low SVR) - may coexist

immediate_stabilization.fluids: Cautious - avoid overloading; may need to diurese if congested
immediate_stabilization.vasopressors: Norepinephrine to maintain MAP ≥65 (better than dopamine)
immediate_stabilization.inotropes: Dobutamine or milrinone to improve CO

revascularization.indication: All patients with MI-related cardiogenic shock
revascularization.strategy: Culprit-lesion only PCI (CULPRIT-SHOCK trial); complete revascularization deferred

mechanical_circulatory_support.IABP: No routine use (IABP-SHOCK II); consider for mechanical complications or as bridge
mechanical_circulatory_support.Impella: Increasing use for LV unloading; limited RCT data
mechanical_circulatory_support.VA_ECMO: Rescue for refractory shock; provides full circulatory support

treat_underlying_cause.mechanical_complications: Emergent surgery for acute MR, VSD, free wall rupture

definition.@value: A state of critical tissue hypoperfusion due to primary failure of the heart as a pump, characterized by low cardiac output, elevated filling pressures, and systemic hypoperfusion

learning_objectives: Define cardiogenic shock using hemodynamic parameters
Identify causes of cardiogenic shock with focus on AMI
Determine indications for mechanical circulatory support
Apply evidence from SHOCK, IABP-SHOCK II, and CULPRIT-SHOCK trials
clinical_pearls: Cold extremities + pulmonary edema + hypotension = cardiogenic shock
SHOCK trial: Early revascularization saves lives in AMI-related shock
CULPRIT-SHOCK: Treat culprit lesion only during index PCI
Norepinephrine preferred over dopamine for vasopressor support
Avoid excessive fluids - most patients are already volume overloaded
